item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment:
Brain-burny, constant involvement, with expansions it scales well from 1 to 6, just the right length, the ability to get better, the chance for doing so poorly you get kicked out, no super-heavy calculations. Freaking genius. Best graph/economic game.
+ England + Ireland + Western US + Germany + Scandinavia + Korea + France + Italy + Pennsylvania + Northern California + 1867 Georgia + South Carolina + Oklahoma Land Rush + Alabama Railways + Antebellum Louisiana + Four Corners + America + Europe + Barbados + St. Lucia + Belgium + Eastern US + Canada + Finland + Portugal + Jamaica + Puerto Rico + Mexico + China + Montreal Metro + Secret Blueprints 1 & 2 + Sun + London + Zombie Apocolypse + Washington D.C. + Berlin Wall + Time Traveler

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
Tricked out with all the MayDay bits (animals, people, items). Almost frustratingly difficult to do well, but I enjoy the effort. Great scalability. Incredible replay value. This game would be a bargain at $100. Best worker-placement game.

item.name: Earth Reborn
item.comment: An amazing creation. Tight euro-style mechanics and tough decisions wrapped inside a very thematic package. Super miniatures, decent back-story, and endlessly extendable. This is a toybox more than a game although the included scenarios are excellent. I haven't been this pleased with a game since acquiring Memoir '44 or Agricola.

item.name: Elasund: The First City
item.comment: A really good game, but after several plays I still don't have the play sequence down. Either my brain is slipping or it's just not intuitive.

item.name: Fields of Fire
item.comment:
Entry for all Fields of Fire games: + Volume 1 - Volume 2 (preordered; late 2015)
Fantastic system once you understand the relatively simple basic rules. Alas, the system has yet to be described in a succinct way. My advice: Don't concern yourself with getting every rule exactly right. Learn the overall design and then just have fun with the system. Accept that your first few games may not adhere exactly to the designer's intentions. In the end, it doesn't matter that much if you actually ran out of ammo or were not in communication. You can add those rules later.
The system is very solid. A few missteps by the player will not invalidate your experience. Eventually, you will get it all down, and when you do, games play very quickly with a lot of replay value. I can't wait for expansions.
FoF is turning into the perfect compliment to ASL. ASL is a tense two-player test of skill. FoF is a solitaire test of will.
While both games model squad-based combat, ASL admittedly fails to model several key elements of combat: the command structure, battlefield communications, and lines of attack. It is precisely these essential characteristics that FoF emphasizes. Because most (FoF designer Ben Hull's Musket and Pike Battle Series is another exception) squad-based comsims neglect command, control, communications and intelligence (C3i), FoF feels like a very strange game. This strangeness (along with sloppy rules writing) is the major cause for players' difficulty comprehending the gameplay.
Why should I have to activate the CO HQ and then activate the First Platoon HQ in order to get the 1/1 squad to move forward and seek cover? Because in FoF, you are playing the role of the company commander. No CO HQ wants his platoons and squads acting independently unless they are under extreme conditions. When an enemy MG nest is found on the right wing of command, the HQ must reassess the situation and move assets into proper position. The HQ in FoF does not have full knowledge of the battlefield until his subordinates report this information back to him. How would the forward 3/2 squad know if it's safe to evacuate casualties? Perhaps the evac site is under fire. The order MUST come down from HQ.
Sure, squads will open fire against a spotted enemy that is firing on them, but they will exhibit little other initiative. In actual combat, squads running across a battlefield on their own initiative are unlikely to survive to the next mission. Squads out of communication with their platoon leader and ultimately the company commander are asking for trouble.
FoF also succeeds in making volume of fire and visibility the primary factors for determining the effect of fire on a unit. The simple tracking of VoF provides the feeling of a realtime combat without the complexity of ASL's interwoven phases. Armed with enough ammunition, even green troops can lay down a steady volume of fire, though veterans will have a much easier time concentrating their fire on a target. Soldiers in the open being hit from multiple directions are going to suffer no matter their mettle.

item.name: High and Tight
item.comment: I've played a lot of baseball board games in the past three decades, and High & Tight is the best. A very unique approach to baseball on your table top. Games of this sport are usually either too simple or too dry. This one has serious strategy, a quick play time, and makes you feel like you are managing an intense game of baseball.

item.name: Magic Realm
item.comment:
Richard Hamblen melded so many innovations together that the game is difficult to start, let alone master. Once you understand combat and the hazards of the realm, you'll find endless variety in a relatively small amount of items, monsters and spells.
I suppose this game will be republished with an expansion or two coming, but the original game with the third edition of the rules is pretty close to perfection.

item.name: Manoeuvre
item.comment: Needs a small piece of plexiglass. I'm not sure if it's a wargame or an abstract, but it's fun, very replayable, quick with virtually no set-up time.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventure on the Cursed Island
item.originalname: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment:
+ Voyage of the Beagle
I love "sandbox" games. ASL is one, Earth Reborn, the C&C games, Space Empires... The rules and components of this game allow players to play it over and over with endless variation. Lots of room for players to make their own scenarios or for the publisher to take the game in new directions with a an expansion or two. One really feels like part of a small band of survivors on a deserted island with this game. Loving it so far.
Just a fabulously tight creation with incredibly tense decisions.

item.comment: Patience solitaire has been being played with a deck of cards since the 1700s. In 2013, SOS Titanic may have provided the theme for this game for all following generations.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment:
I don't generally like co-op games, but Vlaada has fixed all my problems with co-op games in Space Alert. Plus, the theme works great.
Includes New Frontier Expansion

item.name: Space Empires: 4X
item.comment:
The best implementation of bluffing in a combat game that I have ever played. An utterly fantastic toy box of a game that will only get better with an expansion or two. You can experience the satisfying look of horror on your opponent's face when your mysterious fleet moves two spaces in the first movement phase thus outflanking toward his home planet. A phase later you can be the victim as his mines destroy your two dreadnoughts before they can fire a shot. Brilliance.
I expected to dislike the bookkeeping, but it's actually much better than using a screen and a bunch of counters. The benefits of bookkeeping far outweigh the costs.
Combat could have been overly complicated, but it has been fantastically streamlined.
The expansion will seamlessly add more options, but the game is great in its current form.
+ Close Encounters + Replicators
item.wishlistcomment: If well reviewed,short enough play time, and plays well with 2.

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing
item.comment:
I put off trying this game because I'm not a huge Star Wars geek and I did not love Wings of War. My mistake. This game is fantastic. Great choices for customizing your small fleet and a nice cat and mouse game between the players.
+ Tie Bomber + Tie Advanced + Tie Interceptor + Slave 1 + Tie Fighter + Tie Defender + Tie Phantom
+ Millenium Falcon + B-wing + A-wing + HWK-290 + Lambda class shuttle + X-wing + Rebel Transport + Tantive IV + E-wing + Z-95

item.name: StarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment:
The orders system creates some neat tension. I also love the different races and the difficult upgrading decisions. Great bits, of course.
+ Brood War Expansion

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment: Quick, deep, simple to learn. Unfortunately, my dog ate 2 palm trees which I found pooped out in the back yard. Kinda sours the game a bit, but still a favorite.

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: I just hope people will still be playing this game in 50 years. It deserves all praise it gets. Best of the tiling laying games.

item.name: Titan
item.comment: I can't imagine playing with more than 3 players, but a fantastic game with 2 or 3, especially when you can leave it out and play an hour or so now and then.

item.name: Titan: The Arena
item.comment: I own the original version and really enjoy it.

item.name: Top Secret Spies
item.comment: Bluffing again, which I like. Gets a bit random with too many people. Nice with 2 or 3 people.

item.name: Traders of Carthage
item.comment: Brilliant! Not the most exciting game I've ever played, but it's hard to believe how much game you get with a few bits and cards numbered 2, 3, and 5 in 4 colors. Totally elegant.

item.name: Up Front
item.comment:
+ United States + Germany + Soviet Union
Artscow cards plus homemade counters

item.name: Urban Sprawl
item.comment:
A great game experience. It's just fun to build up a city with a group of friends. At first play, the winner will not know why he won, but further plays will show more strategic play. I think this can be a very competitive game with 3 or 4 gamers who know the game well, but at first (like Twilight Struggle) players will be grasping in the dark. Despite that, the game will be fun for new players.
US has an old-school feel. Flip the cards, see what's gonna happen, make some money, lose some points. I love playing this game.
LIKELY TO SELL.
